Psychophysics is an important discipline in this

philosophers such as Immanuel
Kant to be impossible to develop a
quantitative science of psychology
because internal experiences weren't
particularly quantifiable.
But Fechner challenged that notion.
He developed a way of relating
changes in an external stimulus to
changes in internal perception. For example,
if you have a light and you increase the
intensity of that light,
how much do you have to increase the
intensity of the light
before an observer notices the
difference?
Sometimes you can change the actual
intensity and an observer won't even notice the
difference.
In psychology that was called the JND,
or Just Noticeable Difference. When I was
an undergraduate studying psychology at the
University of Wisconsin back in the 1960s
this was considered very important. This
was like the cutting edge
of experimental psychology. I engaged
in experiments at the time based on
Fechner's work
using a device called a tachistoscope,
which basically was a flashing light and
you could vary the intensity
and the speed of the light flashes.
So what we were looking at at that
point was called the critical
fusion frequency, how
fast would the light have to flash
before it seemed as if
it wasn't flashing at all but was a
steady light?
So Fechner developed what was known as
Fechner's Law,
a mathematical relationship between
changes in the stimulus, the external stimulus,
and changes in the internal perception
of that stimulus. Today
psychophysics is regarded as a
legitimate branch of
psychology and it's an important
branch because it is so very
mathematical.
It seems to be a way of unifying
the external world with the internal
world of perception.
Now, an interesting thing about Fechner
is that he was both
an empiricist and I think to some extent a
positivist in the realm of science,
certainly an experimentalist, but he was
also a mystic. He wrote for example
The Little Book of Life After Death. And
you know who wrote

than my hero William
James. But I have to say James went much
further than simply writing an
introduction to Fechner's work.
James, in one of his classic books, A Pluralistic
Universe, really was subscribing to
Fechner's metaphysics. Let me say
a little bit about Fechner. He was born in 1801. He died
in 1887, so he lived 86 years. He had a long
productive life, however
his career was interrupted.
Like William James, he studied medicine. He got a degree in
medicine but he never practiced
medicine. Ironically,
after graduating with his medical degree
he was given a professorship
in physics. He was in his mid
30s as I recall and
at that point he experienced a

lean pork.

it was written tongue-in-cheek, but it

you might even say. He wrote books

In his book, The Little Book of Life

he argues that the human being goes

Then there is this life here on Earth
and in this life we spend half our life

Then our third life, which he would regard as
the afterlife, he said there we are all
conscious, completely conscious.
Now, he went further than that even in

Fechner wrote a book called Zend-
Avesta. It's interesting he would choose
that title because it's
really the same title as some of the

Zarathustra, but it's the title that
Fechner chose. In it he argues

Now, this is a very ancient idea but he

the soul of the universe and that's

So he's thinking in very broad terms like this,
doing rigorous scientific work, inspiring
not only the whole discipline of
experimental
psychology and certainly the
thinking of William
James who was, like Fechner, something of

So he's an inspiration to me,

off-beat nonsensical ideas

the idea of the afterlife,
